Allegheny College will be transitioning all employees who are currently paid on a monthly pay schedule to a biweekly schedule. We anticipate this transition will occur between July 1 and August 1, 2024. It is our intent to present the transition to the campus in an informative manner that reduces any confusion and concern.

As we are getting closer to the transition to bi-weekly payroll, we wanted to direct you to the Human Resources Payroll site that will adequately give you all the resources needed in preparing for this transition. You will find checklists, forms, FAQ’s, and references to support you though this process.

The Office of Human Resources is always available should you require any assistance or guidance with this transition. The extension to call is x2312.

Please have changes and updates to your direct deposit, W4, and 403b contributions completed and turned into the Office of Human Resources by June 21, 2024.

content.rendered:
The campus community is invited to say farewell to Ruth Andel, College Archivist. Please join the Pelletier Library staff for a light brunch reception to honor Ruth on Thursday, May 30 in Merrick Archives, 9:00–10:30 am. Join us as we celebrate Ruth’s 23-year career at Allegheny and wish her well in retirement.

Ruth has tirelessly worked to build and promote the Merrick Archives in courses of history and the public humanities, and ensured archival procedures and preservation standards are followed and upheld. Ruth created and implemented the Archives Records Management Policy for the campus. Her dedication to preservation and promotion of Allegheny College materials and artifacts is unmatched. Ruth has managed the Allegheny College Archives and the Merrick Archival Center, offering research services for both the archives and more recently special collections, including manuscripts, college records, books, photographs, and artifact and digital collections. She offered and assisted with one-on-one research consultations, History and Art Department interns, navigation of DSpace records and JSTOR image collections. She has served the college community as a member of several committees, including LITS, History and Heritage, Bicentennial Planning, and Curriculum Committee.

Archival needs and questions may still be directed to the Merrick Archives email merrick@allegheny.edu.

The Office of URSCA invites all summer students, faculty/staff, administrators, and campus community members to the first Allegheny College’s Research Seminar Series (“ACRoSS”) of the summer on Tuesday 5/21 at noon in the Tillotson Room of the Tippie Alumni Center.

ACRoSS is an interdisciplinary forum for the presentation of summer research projects developed by students and faculty at Allegheny College. Any student who participates in summer programming on campus (or as part of a community-based research project) along with all campus community members are invited each Tuesday to build community, eat lunch, and listen to brief updates about student summer projects. Each week, students present short overviews of their specific summer research projects (e.g., proposed experiments, data, anticipated results) to an audience of students, faculty, and administrators. Free lunch is provided each week!

The schedule of presenters will soon be available on this website.

This weather will not dampen the spirit of this momentous celebration — congratulations again to the Class of 2024!

In keeping with the religious roots of the ceremony, readings by students of different faiths will be offered by:

  • Manasvi Bantawa
  • Simon Jones
  • Rutendo Mavunga
  • Sami Mirza
  • Ankitha Pamula

President Cole, Professor Sharon Wesoky, and ACO Advisor, Mollie Little will also take part. James Niblock and Kevin Dill from the music faculty, along with the Baccalaureate Choir, will provide music.

Seniors, their families, and the Allegheny community are warmly invited to attend to help celebrate the accomplishments of the Class of 2024.

title.rendered: Office 365 A1 Plus For Education Will Retire On August 1, 2024

content.rendered:
Microsoft recently announced that it will be retiring the Office 365 A1 Plus licensing, which grants a free desktop client version of the basic MS Office apps (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint) to anyone at an educational institution. The web browser-based version (A1) will continue to be available, but users will not be able to download the traditional desktop applications.

All college-owned PCs on campus will continue to feature the common Office applications, as our site licensing is not directly tied to this change. These same versions are also available for use in our virtual desktop environment, Apporto (available to all Allegheny community members).

Read Microsoft’s announcement here.

title.rendered: Agenda Items for Faculty Meeting Due by 9 a.m. Monday: 5/6

content.rendered:
Items to be included in the notice of the May 9 Faculty Meeting should be sent to Faculty Secretary Margaret Nelson (mnelson@allegheny.edu) by 9 a.m. on Monday, May 6.

title.rendered: Faculty Recital: Wei En Chan, countertenor 5/3

content.rendered:
Come enjoy a delightful evening of popular 17th-century arias composed by Handel and Vivaldi, performed by music faculty members Wei En Chan and Kevin Dill on May 3 at 7:30 pm in Ford Memorial Chapel. Free admission!

Wei En Chan is a countertenor from Singapore whose singing is lauded for its “time-stopping” beauty and technical finesse. He leads an active career in Asia and North America performing lead roles in the works of Bach and Handel. Highlights include the title role in Handel’s Oreste with the 2019 Singapore International Festival of Arts, alto solos in Bach’s B minor mass & St. Matthew Passion with Bachfest Malaysia, Ruggiero in Handel’s Alcina with The Opera People, Cupid in John Blow’s Venus & Adonis with the Cambridge Chamber Ensemble, and Orlofsky in Strauss’ Die Fledermaus with the Singapore Lyric Opera. Wei En also interpreted the role of Ircano in Chatham Baroque & Quantum Theatre’s ambitious 2022 revival of Broschi’s Idaspe to much acclaim.

Kevin Dill is Allegheny’s Instructor of Organ and College Organist. He serves as an accompanist for the college’s choral ensembles and has been the Music Director of the First Presbyterian Church of Meadville since 2006.

content.rendered:
As you pack up and move out for the semester, please consider how to be most sustainable with items you no longer need or want. Can you donate or recycle that item in the collection locations placed in your residence hall?

  • DONATE: Donation carts will be placed in all residence halls (check your lounge, laundry room, or kitchenette) by mid-week. Please donate any items that are worthy of reuse, clean, dry, and undamaged. Items may include clothing, shoes, furniture, furnishings, bedding and linens, appliances, electronics, books, office supplies, kitchen items, housewares, athletic and sporting goods, music, games, and decorations. Please do not donate junk. Do not donate items you wouldn’t offer a friend – if it’s damaged, ripped, stained, not functioning, just plain worn out, or perishable.
  • RECYCLE: Move-out is no exception to the rule that Allegheny always recycles plastic (#1 & 2), metal, cardboard, and paper. Recycle these items in any waste collection location in the labeled recycling bin.
  • ELECTRONICS: You can donate working appliances and electronics (clear all personal data first) or you can recycle damaged items in the electronics waste collection cage in the back of the Campus Center lobby.

Got questions? Contact sustainability@allegheny.edu.

title.rendered: Gaza on the brink of famine: An interdisciplinary panel 4/24- TODAY

content.rendered:
Join us today – Wednesday, April 24 from 12:20-1:20 pm in Quigley 101 for a discussion of the current humanitarian situation in Gaza, with particular emphasis on food and nutrition.

This discussion will feature panelists from several different academic disciplines:

  • Adrienne Krone (ESS, Religious Studies, Jewish Studies)
  • Reem Hilal (World Languages and Cultures)
  • Amelia Finaret (GHS)
  • Moderator: Professor Shanna Kirschner (Political Science)

The panelists will analyze aspects of the current humanitarian situation from multiple disciplinary lenses, with the hope of providing information and opening up a space for the community to discuss.

This event is sponsored by the Center for Political Participation.

title.rendered: Summer Housing Application For Student Employees

content.rendered:
As we head toward the end of the semester, the Summer Housing Application is now live. Summer housing is geared towards students engaged in summer research, grant-funded internships, or summer student employment. Applications are due May 5, 2024 at 11:59 PM. Summer housing is subject to approval.

Summer housing will be in Allegheny Commons and College Court at $60/day for a room and meal plan. Summer housing formally runs from May 19 to July 28. Students whose research begins on May 20 and students who begin summer employment at Allegheny College as soon as graduation is over may stay on campus after May 13.

Dining will take place at McKinley’s dining hall. Students will receive 19 meal swipes and $20 in munch money per week. For hours of operation, please visit the Summer Housing and Food page on the Financial Services website.

Limited need-based assistance may be available through the Gator Success Grant program.

If you have any questions, please contact Residence Life at reslife@allegheny.edu.

title.rendered: The Zingale Big Idea Competition Starts This Week! 4/26

content.rendered:
The Zingale Big Idea Competition starts this Friday beginning at 9:30 am at the Campus Center. This year 38 students across 21 teams from six colleges – Allegheny College, Carnegie Mellon University, Duquesne University, Grove City College, Geneva College and Westminster College – will compete for $30,000 in prize money!

Exciting news for 2024! The contest finals are set to happen at the Allegheny Lab for Innovation & Creativity (ALIC@Bessemer). This unique space, a blend of business incubator, training site, classroom, and research lab, aims to inspire Zingale participants while promoting regional innovation and economic growth.

You can go! Have you every wondered what it’s like to compete? Maybe you’d like to know what kinds of businesses the students are proposing — if yes, come to the Campus Center on Friday, April 26, rooms 301,302, and 303 from 9:30 am until 2:30 pm to observe the competition.

About the competition: The Zingale Big Idea Competition focuses on seed-level new business ideas. This contest emulates the experiences seen on the popular CNBC broadcast, Shark Tank, but with a heart. Unlike Shark Tank, the Zingale Big Idea distinguished panel of judges do more than evaluate business models – they offer constructive feedback, coaching and encouragement. Learn more here

title.rendered: Summer Housing Application For Student Employees

content.rendered:
As we head toward the end of the semester, the Summer Housing Application is now live. Summer housing is geared towards students engaged in summer research, grant-funded internships, or summer student employment. Applications are due May 5, 2024 at 11:59 PM. Summer housing is subject to approval.

Summer housing will be in Allegheny Commons and College Court at $60/day for a room and meal plan. Summer housing formally runs from May 19 to July 28. Students whose research begins on May 20 and students who begin summer employment at Allegheny College as soon as graduation is over may stay on campus after May 13.

Dining will take place at McKinley’s dining hall. Students will receive 19 meal swipes and $20 in munch money per week. For hours of operation, please visit the Summer Housing and Food page on the Financial Services website.

Limited need-based assistance may be available through the Gator Success Grant program.

If you have any questions, please contact Residence Life at reslife@allegheny.edu.

title.rendered: Senior Week Tickets On Sale Until 4/29

content.rendered:
Now is your chance to purchase your Senior Week 2024 tickets online starting today! Ticket sales will end on April 29 at 5 pm; so don’t wait to go online to the link below, complete the online form, and purchase your ticket for just $15.

Each graduating Senior is permitted to buy only one ticket and guests are not permitted at Senior Week events. Only Seniors participating in the Commencement Ceremony on May 11 are permitted to buy a ticket for Senior Week.

You must pay upon completion of this form. If you do not pay, your registration is not complete or confirmed.

Senior Week 2024 events include:

  • Tuesday, May 7 – Late Night Dinner at McKinley’s at 9 pm
  • Tuesday, May 7 – Bar Crawl: Join your fellow classmates from 10pm-1am for a bus loop around Meadville sampling specials at each local bar. Bus pick up and drop off on Highland Ave behind the Campus Center.
  • Wednesday, May 8 – Senior BBQ- 1 pm-3 pm at the Robertson Athletic Pavilion. Enjoy some tasty BBQ and toast the Class of 2024 farewell.
  • Wednesday, May 8 – Taste of Meadville Block Party & Wellness Fire from 6-9 pm. Come taste all your favorite Meadville foods one last time, music, vendors from local restaurants on the Gator Quad and NV Quad. Bring copies of your COMP to release in the Wellness Fire.
  • Thursday, May 9 -Senior Grad Ball: A fun night with wonderful food, drinks and dancing starting at 8 pm at the Meadville Country Club and a two drink max cash bar. Enjoy the rest of the night by dancing! Event runs 8 pm-10 pm. Bus pick up and drop off is on Highland Ave behind the Campus Center.
  • Friday, May 10 – GFC Farewell Brunch from 11 am-1 pm in Grounds for Change. Grab some coffee, juice, bagels and pastries from GFC as we prepare to say farewell for now.
  • Friday, May 10- Seniors Farewell Walk of Campus at 8:30 pm. Meet at Senior Circle and take one last walk of campus with surprises along the way as a Class.

For more information, contact Senior Class Dean Dr. Jonathon May at jmay@allegheny.edu or the Class of 2024 Officers at asg@allegheny.edu.

content.rendered:
Attention current first and second-year students!

Second-Year Class Dean Amy Stearns will be assembling a second-year task force which will work together next fall and spring to identify and address areas of improvement for the second-year experience at Allegheny in response to recently collected survey data.

The group will be composed of second- and third-year students and will meet most Fridays for one hour at lunchtime. Additional outside work up to an hour a week will be required at times.

Meetings will be augmented by training sessions with Allegheny alumni, faculty, and/or staff, adding a professional development component to the experience. If you are interested in being part of the Second-Year Task Force, please submit this form.

If you are interested and have questions, please email Amy at astearns@allegheny.edu.

title.rendered: Gaza on the brink of famine: An interdisciplinary panel 4/24

content.rendered:
Join us Wednesday, April 24 from 12:20-1:20 pm in Quigley 101 for a discussion of the current humanitarian situation in Gaza, with particular emphasis on food and nutrition.

This discussion will feature panelists from several different academic disciplines:

  • Adrienne Krone (ESS, Religious Studies, Jewish Studies)
  • Reem Hilal (World Languages and Cultures)
  • Amelia Finaret (GHS)

Moderator: Professor Shanna Kirschner (Political Science)

The panelists will analyze aspects of the current humanitarian situation from multiple disciplinary lenses, with the hope of providing information and opening up a space for the community to discuss.

This event is sponsored by the Center for Political Participation.

Authors whose work is selected for publication will be partnered with student editors in the Fall 2024 Editing and Publishing course.

Please direct any questions to Professor Alexis Hart at ahart@allegheny.edu. The deadline for submissions is June 3, 2024.

title.rendered: Summer Internship Housing Support in D.C., Erie, and NYC!

content.rendered:
Gators, have you secured a summer internship in D.C., Erie, or NYC? The Career Center is proud to have connections, through local universities and housing services, that provide students with reliable residential living, some even including free public transportation passes.

Additionally, students can apply to our internship funding program through Handshake which provides funds to offset the cost of housing, meals, and transportation – the deadline is May 1.

Please email Autumn Parker <aparker> to schedule an appointment to discuss housing options and/or the internship funding application.

content.rendered:
The Allegheny College Choirs will present their spring concert on Saturday, April 20, at 3:15 pm in Shafer Auditorium. The concert is free and open to the public.

The Allegheny College Choir, Soprano-Alto Chorale, and Tenor-Bass Ensemble will each perform several works in a variety of musical styles from composers Casals, Krenek, Schubert, Parker, Luvaas, and more.

Before closing, the three choirs will join together as one collective choir of students and community members to sing their final pieces, “O Love” by Elaine Hagenberg and “Nda Wana” by Micheal Barrett.

The concert will feature numerous student soloists in vocal and percussion roles. The ensembles will be conducted by Prof. James Niblock, and Kevin Dill will accompany them on piano. Prof. Michael Dolan will join as a guest conductor.

title.rendered: Today is the 10th Annual Gator Give Day: 4/18

content.rendered:
Today, April 18, is the 10th Annual Gator Give Day! Students, be sure to join us in the Campus Center Lobby from 11 am to 2 pm for snacks, giveaways, and fun! There will be t-shirts, chocolate-covered pretzels, and an opportunity to support Allegheny.

If we hit our goal of 150 students making a donation of ANY size, a member of the Board of Trustees will sponsor a Casey’s ice cream social on campus on Study Day (May 1) for ALL students. Not to mention that your participation has the potential to help unlock a $1 MILLION DOLLAR challenge for Allegheny.

Also, keep an eye on Allegheny social for fun videos throughout the day! Thank you to all who plan to participate and to our excellent volunteers. Please join us, and let’s celebrate together!

To celebrate the research accomplishments of the Class of 2024, the Biology Department is pleased to host its Twenty-Sixth Annual Senior Project Symposium on Monday and Tuesday afternoons, April 22 and 23. Graduating seniors will present the results of their senior project research in sessions beginning at 1:10 p.m. each afternoon.

All members of the college community are invited and welcome to attend. Juniors, sophomores, and first-year students who have an interest in Biology are especially encouraged to attend and participate.

Please contact the Symposium Coordinator at kberger@allegheny.edu for more information. A schedule of the symposium presentations may be viewed on the biology website.
